sentence: C all it equal parts plague and revolution.

Organized crime, unfriendly nations and dissidents are using increasingly cheap technology and new platforms such as smartphones and cloud computing to launch cyberattacks on thousands of companies and millions of individuals at a time.
In response, governments and cybersecurity software makers are banding together to stop them.
So far, it's a standoff.

Jeff Scheel, vice president of corporate development, alliances and strategy atSymantec ( SYMC ), the largest independent cybersecurity software maker, recounts a large money-center banking client that was hit despite very tight network security policies.
"Attackers compromised the country club where the bulk of executives played golf.
The golf club regularly sent out PDF documents on upcoming tournaments.
No one violated company policy," Scheel said.
"But every single executive opened the PDF and it was loaded with 17 different kinds of malware."
Among the latest attacks, on Monday, Feb. 16, Russian cybersecurity company Kaspersky Lab said that thieves infiltrated more than 100 banks in 30 countries over the past two years.
The estimated take: as much as $1 billion.
The Kaspersky account, first reported by the New York Times on Feb. 14, said thieves gained access to the unnamed banks' computers via email phishing schemes and other scams.
The attackers studied the banks' operations and even programmed ATM machines to dispense money at certain times.
The investigation is ongoing.
No.
2 U.S. health care insurer,Anthem ( ANTM ), on Feb. 4 said that hackers had gained access to a database of personal records on as many as 80 million current and former customers and employees.
Names, birth dates and Social Security numbers were reportedly stolen, but not credit card numbers.
Anthem employees spotted the breach.
The company quickly reported it to the FBI and hired cybersecurity firmFireEye ( FEYE ) to investigate.
A FireEye spokesman told Reuters, "We do confirm that this was done by an advanced group using custom malware."
Other headline attacks last year includedHome Depot ( HD ),Target ( TGT ),JPMorgan Chase (JPM) andSony (SNE).
Federal agencies have also been hacked, including a suspected cyberattack that shut down the State Department's unclassified email system in November, and appeared to target the White House, AP said.
Among all of those, the Sony hack triggered special attention from the White House.
The government said the attack originated from North Korea, perhaps in response to the Sony movie "The Interview," a spoof depicting an attempted assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

Calling the Sony hack a "game changer," Lisa Monaco, President Obama's homeland security and counterterrorism adviser, on Feb. 10 announced formation of the Cyber Threat Intelligence Integration Center (CTIIC), which will pull together all imminent-threat data under a single agency and disseminate it to other government agencies.

President Obama also convened a much-publicized cybersecurity summit in Silicon Valley on Friday, Feb. 13, attended by CEOs atApple (AAPL),Intel (INTC),American Express (AXP) and other companies.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) CEO Mark McLaughlin was at that summit.
Last year, President Obama named McLaughlin chairman of the National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee (NSTAC), a group of tech company CEOs that advise the administration.
"The summit was designed with one major theme, to stress the importance of information sharing," McLaughlin told IBD.
"Cyber threat intel sharing as a way to combat all things bad is not a new idea.
But what the president was trying to do was make a number of proposals to bring together lots of leaders in the industry."

The administration made cybersecurity a top priority after a devastating series of attacks at large companies in 2014 collectively led to more than 500 million customers' bank records and payment cards being compromised.

Meanwhile, large and small corporations are ramping up cybersecurity software purchases from companies such as Palo Alto Networks, Symantec, FireEye,CyberArk Software (CYBR),Check Point Software (CHKP) andFortinet (FTNT).
This has led the Computer Software-Security group to a No.
7 rank on Friday among IBD's list of 197 industries.
FireEye on Feb. 11 announced better-than-expected earnings, and its stock climbed to a seven-month high the next day.
Palo Alto Networks has hit a succession of new all-time highs.

A blowout fourth quarter and bullish outlook on Q1 sent CyberArk, which launched its initial public offering in September, up 100% in February, clearing a double-bottom base buy point of 53.59 along the way.
"This is a white-hot space that has been showing no signs of slowing," FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives said.

Hackers Need Just One Way In

Ives' favorites in the sector are Palo Alto, which is on the IBD Leaderboard list of top-rated stocks, and Check Point.
"Palo Alto is a lot like the LeBron James of firewalls.
And Check Point has a 55% operating margin.
It's the gold standard for operating profitability."
IDC estimates that the worldwide information technology security products market grew 6.7% in 2014 to a total $32.6 billion revenue.
The researcher forecasts the market will grow at a compound annual rate of 6.9% from 2013 to 2018, when it will hit $42.8 billion.
Because it's not a direct revenue or profit generator, "nobody willingly spends money on security," IDC Research Director Peter Lindstrom said.
But companies see the scope of recent breaches and are forced to boost spending.
"The bottom line is, an attacker just has to find one way in.
It's a cliche but it's true."
McLaughlin agrees -- a hacker just has to be right one time to win.
"One big trend in favor of bad actors is that the cost of compute power continues to come down.
That means they can launch more attacks at lower cost," McLaughlin said.
But there's a countertrend working in favor of security companies, he says.
"Our approach is to say when someone attacks you they have to get five or six things right to get through that one time.
We're pursuing prevention at each of those points.
If you defeat them at any point, you prevent the attack."
By flipping the odds, the cost of mounting attacks more than offsets the decline in the cost of mounting an attack.
Palo Alto shares on Friday traded 232% above their July 2012 IPO price.
Revenue in the last three years grew from $255 million to a projected $848.4 million for 2015, according to consensus estimates.
Earnings have kept pace, increasing at a double- or triple-digit rate in five of the last six quarters.

Group heavyweight Symantec, with $6.62 billion in annual sales, offers a variety of products on a platform that includes advanced threat detection and features, including simulations that mimic what an actual attack would do.
"It's similar to a live-fire simulation from a military standpoint," Symantec's Scheel said.
There have been no reports yet of a large-scale breach by hackers using smartphones as an attack platform, he noted, but added that it's inevitable.
"Sophistication of attacks on those types of devices, and on cloud resources where we don't connect through a traditional network, becomes a source for more point attacks," Scheel said.
Both Palo Alto and Symantec are members of the Cyber Threat Alliance, a group of security companies that have banded together to share threat intelligence.
"The Cyber Threat Alliance was formed about six months ago," McLaughlin said.
"It's the first time security companies have agreed to share information.
We have horizontal threat intelligence sharing now.
It's a big step up."
Jim Halpert, head of global cybersecurity at law firm DLA Piper, says his company has advised more than 450 clients on legal ramifications of cyberattacks over the last 10 years.
Halpert sees the development of industry alliances and the government's effort to coordinate responses as a step in the right direction.
Looking ahead, Halpert said, "The state of cybersecurity is improving, but we have a long way to go."
"One positive trend is a greater appreciation of risk management.
And another is (rising) expenditures for defense."
On the downside, "Another trend is increased specialization of attackers.
For example, now we have very sophisticated attackers who hack and then rent hacked networks to others.
We're seeing a real market for company networks in particular."
IDC's Lindstrom says "it's naive to think you can be completely secure."
The key, he said, is understanding your enemy.
"To the extent we can do a better job of understanding our intelligent adversary, we can win.
Without an intelligent adversary, there is no battle."
